title: Part 1 — A Simple, Honest Light/Dark Theme
bodyHtml:
The entire site switches theme by toggling data-theme on the <html> element. Colours are defined with CSS variables, so every component updates at once. A short script stores your choice in localStorage and, when there’s no choice, respects the operating system’s preference. The button reflects reality—its label and aria-pressed update as the theme changes.

An early inline snippet prevents a flash of the wrong theme while the page is loading. It’s only a few lines and it makes a real difference.

title: Part 2 — Rendering the Blog with the Fetch API
bodyHtml:
Posts live in a small JSON file. The blog fetches that file, sorts entries from newest to oldest, and maps each one to a clean card with a title, date, tags, and body. If the network misbehaves, the script shows a clear message instead of failing quietly. While the request is in flight, a lightweight skeleton holds the layout steady.

No libraries are involved; the code is short enough to read at a glance.

title: Fragments — One Header and One Footer for the Whole Site
bodyHtml:
The header and footer are loaded into placeholders with fetch(). This keeps navigation consistent and ensures the theme button appears on every page. The footer year is set at runtime, so it stays current without edits.

Small touches—a skip link, focus rings, and aria-current on the active link—make the pages more comfortable to navigate.
